awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Narrative interface technology to support two-way human-computer interaction for the disabled community
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve software accessibility for the roughly 61 million Americans living with a disability. Interactive technology is not currently standardized, and end-users must rely on accessibility features built into software which are inconsistent or nonexistent. The proposed accessibility interface will enable end-users to utilize 80% of commercially-available software, improving the standard of living for individuals with disabilities and allowing them to engage online professionally and socially. Simultaneously, the innovation will allow software distributors to provide low-cost accessibility solutions, fulfill required mandates, and increase their products’ use and revenue. The innovation will overcome previous limitations for state-of-the-art accessibility solutions as it will be able to accommodate high-intensity software such as augmented reality (AR). It will also be backward-compatible, adding functionality to older platforms and providing a robust and enduring competitive advantage. US-based medical technology companies, game developers, and organizations with accessibility mandates will be initially targeted.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to provide interactive technology accessibility for blind, deaf, and physically disabled users without necessitating additional accessibility hardware. A machine learning (ML) engine will translate visual data into text blocks delivered via text or text-to-speech, with visual information recognized through embedded data. Natural language processing (NLP) will be used to bind actions to spoken phrases, allowing the end-user complete control of the integrated software. This project will test the interface’s ability to integrate with personal productivity software, web browsers, and a video game, with the goal of enabling users to attain 95% functionality across 80% of software on the market. The research and development will involve: i) training the ML engine to use embedded data to reinterpret visual data as text and produce dynamically-created sentences listing all interactive objects within the user’s field of influence, ii) developing the controller interface, which will be driven by user input, listen for approved phrases, and activate desired software controls, and iii) expanding the interface’s versatility by creating and implementing ML protocols to add accessibility features to any existing or future software. The result will be an early prototype with moderate-to-full functionality across selected software.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report: Enhancing Digital Accessibility through the Narrative Interface

Imagine navigating a digital world where every application, website, or software is seamlessly accessible, regardless of physical abilities. Our project aimed to make this vision a reality by developing the Narrative Interface, a groundbreaking technology designed to enhance digital accessibility for people with disabilities.

What is the Narrative Interface?

The Narrative Interface is an innovative system that translates on-screen information into descriptive audio or text, allowing users to interact with digital environments through natural language. It consists of two main components:

  1. Narrative Engine (Reciever): This component interprets the digital environment and available actions, converting them into a descriptive narrative.
  2. Narrative Engine (Transmitter): This allows users to provide input using natural language commands, enabling them to control and navigate applications effortlessly.

Addressing a Critical Need

Many existing assistive technologies require expensive hardware or are limited to specific applications, making them inaccessible to many users. Our goal was to create a universal, low-cost solution that doesn't rely on specialized equipment or constant internet connectivity. By establishing a standardized communication protocol, similar to how closed captioning works for television, the Narrative Interface bridges the accessibility gap across a wide range of software and devices.

Key Achievements and Findings

  • Design and Development: We successfully specified and developed the Narrative Interface, including the communication protocol and a modular code library that developers can integrate into existing software.
  • Innovative Architecture: A significant breakthrough was the realization that separating the system into a hardware transmitter and a software receiver enhances performance and adaptability across different applications.
  • Beta Testing: Initial testing showed that once the communication protocol is established for one type of software, it can be easily adapted to others, demonstrating the system's scalability.

Challenges Overcome

As this was our first large-scale project, we faced challenges in managing timelines and project scope. We learned the importance of focusing on core functionalities first, which led us to refine the dual-component system for better reliability. This focus ensured that we delivered a robust Minimum Viable Product (MVP) that effectively demonstrates the Narrative Interface's potential.

Impact on Accessibility

The Narrative Interface has the potential to revolutionize how individuals with disabilities interact with digital environments:

  • Inclusivity: By removing the need for expensive assistive hardware, we make digital platforms more accessible to a broader audience.
  • Ease of Use: Users can control applications using natural language, reducing the learning curve and making technology more approachable.
  • Adaptability: Developers can easily integrate the Narrative Interface into their software, promoting widespread adoption.

Path to Commercialization

The positive reception from the tech industry underscores the project's significance:

  • Patent Acquisition: We have accepted an offer from tech company Infinite Reality to purchase the full patent for the Narrative Interface. They plan to integrate this technology into their systems, which will significantly expand its reach.
  • Market Interest: Other tech firms have also expressed interest, indicating strong market demand for accessible technology solutions.

Looking Forward

The adoption of the Narrative Interface by major industry players like Infinite Reality paves the way for a more inclusive digital future. As the technology is integrated into more platforms, we anticipate a significant improvement in the quality of life for individuals with disabilities, empowering them to engage with digital content on equal footing with others.

Conclusion

Our project successfully developed a scalable, user-friendly solution to a critical accessibility challenge. By combining innovative technology with a focus on universal design, the Narrative Interface stands to make a lasting impact on society, fostering greater inclusion and equal opportunity in the digital realm.
